Award.AwardTitle: BCC: Broadband Use Mapping, Data and Evaluation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
SMA-1338471
Caroline Tolbert
Colin Gordon
Kevin Leicht
Julianna Pacheco
The University of Iowa

Karen Mossberger
Arizona State University

Broadband has been called the most important infrastructure challenge of the 21st century by the National Broadband Plan. But, it is broadband use rather than availability of infrastructure that enables the access to information, communication and services that is at the heart of broadband's promise. For theory and for public policy, more needs to be known about broadband use by individuals, organizations, and communities, including geographic variation. This project has two dimensions: 1) The construction of a new nationwide dataset that will provide local data on broadband usage that can be analyzed to understand geographic variation in broadband use and its impact on outcomes in areas such as economic development, health, education, and more. 2) Fostering an interdisciplinary broadband research community through the creation of a portal/repository for broadband evaluation research and data, a conference, and a seed fund competition for new types of broadband data. This study expands prior research in Chicago and other select cities to map nationally Internet use and online political, economic and human capital-enhancing activities. Statistical modeling will be used to create biannual estimates of Internet use and online activities for every county in the United States, all metropolitan areas and the nation's 50 largest cities. This will create a longitudinal dataset of 20 years that does not currently exist. We will use available respondents in the Current Population Survey (CPS) annual Internet Use Supplement from 1995-2015, merged with aggregate census tract level data measuring socioeconomic conditions of neighborhoods. For Chicago, Los Angeles and New York City, the nation's three largest cities, we will create estimates of Internet use across community areas or neighborhoods. Multi-layered maps based on this data will be made publicly available through the portal, using GIS software and open source online platforms such as those used by Worldmap at Harvard University. This data will provide a unique view of geographic variation in technology use over time, which can be used by researchers to examine social change and measure social impacts for technology use. Interaction across policy areas and disciplines can help researchers to better understand causal mechanisms or the conditions under which technology use matters for a variety of outcomes. Activities for building an interdisciplinary research community include sharing of the dataset and maps on a portal with a repository and discussion platform, and a seed fund to promote further experimentation with new methods of broadband data collection. A conference will be held to further develop the portal and to reach out to networks of broadband evaluation researchers and broadband data experts.

Broader Impacts:
As information, services, and activities have migrated online, Internet use has become a necessity for full participation in society. But inequality in access remains a barrier and better information on how broadband is actually used is needed to guide public policy. Data on geographic variation can inform policy decisions about targeting and program planning, and can be used to track the impact of local or neighborhood trends or interventions in areas such as health or education. In addition, we propose an interdisciplinary collaboration to gather various types of data and evaluation research on broadband use, in order to offer better guidance for policymakers about trends and best practice.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the twenty-first century information access and participation in society are increasingly digital. Existing data measuring Internet use in the U.S. has relied on national surveys from U.S. Census Bureau’s Current Population Survey (CPS) and more recently the American Community Survey (ACS), the Pew Research Center’s Internet and American Life Program or other individual-level private data sources. Our knowledge of inequalities in Internet use is primarily based on individual demographic factors, such as wealth and income, educational attainment, racial and ethnic groups, age groups, language groups, and other demographic factors. We know much less about digital inequalities across local geographic communities, including counties, urban areas (metros) or the nation’s principal cities. Yet inequalities in digital access create significant disadvantages for individuals and communities in competing in a global economy, managing critical public services, creating civic connections, and more. Poverty is a primary driver of digital inequality. Poverty, like the digital divide, is increasingly shaped by place and geographic communities. Digital inequality has a spatial component as well as an individual component.

For both policymakers and researchers interested in the nexus between technology use and sustainability at the local level, for communities planning projects and requesting support from the Broadband Opportunity Council, subnational data is needed to measure disparities in Internet access and use for local communities. This is particularly true as different forms of Internet access have emerged – including high-speed broadband and mobile access.  The adoption of different forms of access has implications for its use – for speed, mobility, and functionality of Internet access. 

The outcome of this grant is a new national dataset of population estimates of these various forms of access and Internet use across communities. We leverage data science, advanced statistical modeling and data from the Census to generate population estimates of Internet access in communities across the United States.  No previous data exists for the time period and local geographic areas reported in this grant. The data reported here are estimates of proportion of the population using the Internet; this compares started with current federal government broadband maps which show where the Internet is available to purchase (infrastructure mapping). We have also laid the foundation for future work utilizing new data sources to track broadband and Internet use at the subnational level, using big data collected by Catalist. Catalist data is used to estimate population Internet access for all 3100 U.S. counties, numbers that are not available from the Census or Factfinder.

The estimates from the Census data are mapped--for the nation’s fifty largest metropolitan areas and principle cities, states and counties--improving data visualization and making the results publicly accessible. Multilevel statistical models and very large sample data (Census’s Current Population Survey and American Community Survey, Catalist) are used to create the population estimates of broadband and mobile use for communities. While the American Community Survey (ACS) provides data on some communities for 2013-2014, this project offers time series data, estimates for counties not in the ACS, and also richer demographic data not available in the ACS.

Funded by NSF Award No. 1338471, a new public dataset was made available in January 2016 via a data repository portal at Arizona State University’s Center for Policy Informatics in collaboration with researchers at the University of Iowa. The repository is located at https://policyinformatics.asu.edu/broadband-data-...
